comments.content: Heartwarming. Not sure why the cashier was interrogating her choice in the first place. People aren't born racist, racism is learned. Kudos to the parent, she's obviously doing something right.
Why does it matter if the doll looks like her, it's a doll not a replica someone made of her. The cashier didn't need to comment
Internet Court Transcript:  Internet Judge: "Has the internet Jury reached a verdict on the matter of the cashier?" ... See More

When my daughter was little she had a friend who was 'mixed race'  (hope it's O.K. to say that) and she came home one day and said " I wish I had a suntan like Mandy".. Nearly 50 years later they are still friends.  :)   :)   The only race in the world is the human race!!!

I had a black baby doll when I was young and I loved her! When I asked my mom if I could get one, she said of course I could have one. Back then in the 50s, there weren't many to have, but I found the baby doll that was perfect for me.
Racism is taught, you are not born with it. Children should be taught that there is only one race of people, the human race.

I dont think the cashier was trying to be racist. I think she was just letting the girl know that there are dolls that look like her and thought maybe the girl couldnt find one. I mean awesome for the little girl for seeing past color, but i dont think the cashier was trying to be rude.
This is how you eradicate racism...it starts at home between children and parents. Just remember, we enter this world as beautiful, innocent human beings. Nobody is born a racist.

A 2yr old smarter then most people for one cashier doesn't need to say the doll don't look like her n the little girl told the truth she sees a pretty girl n doc. Amazing how she sees that n not color that's how we should all look at each other as human beings

We need so many more Sophia's so that this scene will be a norm. It is sad that in 2017 instead of going forward we are going backwards.  Thank you, sweet Sophia. Teach the WORLD!!! You are in my eyes pure  <3 .

Absolutely heart warming! She only saw a doll that she shared an interest with (being a doctor) and how she is pretty! No one is born racist, it's a learnt trait. I don't believe the cashier should be fired but maybe made aware that what she said came across poorly. It's understandable that maybe most toddlers will choose a doll that resembles them and in this case, Sophia did, just wasn't in the skin color sense.

Keep your children away from , hate , religion you will see the results ,, they are amazing I have 4 kids I keep them away from any hate and religion ,, they are the best in school!  Do what ever you want!

I wish there was a video of me on FB as a child with my plethora of white dolls lol  oh wait...I didn't have a choice back then. (totally being facetious here) I see what they are trying to say in this video, but we know that, as children pick out green, purple, red, etc. dolls ex. Monster High.

The little girl picked the doll because she probably watches "Doc McStuffins".  Maybe the cashier was curious and never heard of the show.  At least I hope that's why she asked.  So cute that the little girl explained why she was buying it.

I think the most interesting part of this is that the little white girl saw herself as a doctor, and she saw in front of herself a black doll who was a doctor. Why highlight that she thought "we're both pretty girls"? She said first, we're both doctors! To me, it shows how important it is to have black representation across occupations!

I'm sorry but why is that cashier asking about that child's doll? Why is she questioning anything about a customers items that are being purchased? It's a sweet story and that little girl is amazing but she shouldn't have had to explain herself to anybody.

A little girl setting the example for people all over the world ha. This shouldn't be an issue to begging with because that's not how the world is suppose to be, unfortunately is full of racism and hate .

I find it incredibly hard to believe that the cashier asked the girl about her choice in dolls. Especially at a Target. I work for Target, and they are an incredibly progressive company. In my experience, they hire a majority of progressive employees with great social skills. This for sure is not a good social skill to interrogate a child with her choice of toy.

There's nothing wrong with the cashier asking her about her preference. We read too much to things. I can ask anyone, just out of curiosity & also testing children's intelligence of their choice of anything.
